newsitem.title: USA: US Treasuries narrowly lower at midday.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries narrowly lower at midday.

text.p: U.S. Treasury prices remained narrrowly lower at midday on Tuesday as dealers positioned themselves for new supply.
The Treasury will sell $18.25 billion in two-year notes shortly. The deadline for bids is 1300 EDT/1700 GMT. Auction results are due around 1340 EDT.
On Wednesday, the Treasury will sell $12.5 billion in five-year notes on Wednesday.
The market opened lower, at much the same levels that it was trading at in the early afternoon.
The market treaded down to its session lows on news that the BTM/Schroders U.S. adjusted chain store sales index rose 0.8 percent in the October 19 week versus the prior week.
The Redbook chain store sales report is due at 1455 EDT/1855 GMT.
The other data on tap for later this afternoon is not expected to move the market.
September federal budget figures, due at 1400 EDT/1800 GMT, are expected to show a monthly budget surplus of $29.4 billion after a deficit of $41.83 billion in August.

Analysts said the market is focusing on supply. Two-year Treasury notes were last auctioned on September 25. At that time the notes were sold at an average yield of 6.08 percent. A six percent coupon was awarded to the $18.26 billion in two-year notes sold. The bid-to-cover ratio was 2.64 and the auction attracted non-competitive bids totaling $1.45 billion.
In when-issued trade shortly before this two-year note auction, the notes were yielding 5.94 percent.
Analysts at MMS International said technical indicators have "eased off from their overbought position, pointing to additional gains once supply is cleared."
In when-issued trade, the five-year Treasury notes to be auctioned on Wednesday were yielding 6.28 percent.
Three-month bill rates were down one basis point to 4.99 percent. Six-month bill rates were up one basis point to 5.13 percent.
Year bill rates were up two basis points to 5.26 percent.
The 6-1/2 percent ten-year note was down 5/32 to 99-23/32 to yield 6.54 percent.
Dipping in early afternoon trade again, the 6-3/4 percent 30-year bond was down 7/32 to 99-2/32, yielding 6.82 percent.
